newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices down 1/8, deals loom.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices down 1/8, deals loom.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond prices dipped about 1/8 point in early trade as players waited for close to $2.2 billion of new competitive and negotiated supply to hit Tuesday's market.
"We're waiting on supply, that's the deal, that's the whole deal today," one trader said, adding that pricing largely will determine how supply fares.
"I think you need a little price concession to get it well received," the trader said.
"Their minds are focused elsewhere. A 5-1/2 percent 20 (year), 30-year bond doesn't do anything for them, and do you blame them?"
Competition for the retail investor's dollar grows every year, he said, citing stocks as one example.

"When I started in this business, muni buyers were muni buyers, they never bought anything else," the trader said. "Now the next generation who has money is looking at a lot of different things, and it's got to be attractive."

The day's competitive deals include a $500 million California offering scheduled for 1200 EDT, while a $459 million New York City Transit Authority deal via Dillon Read & Co tops Tuesday's negotiated slate.
A trader who focuses on New Jersey paper said that state "has a calendar this week for the first time in a long time."

He estimated the New Jersey calendar at close to $900 million. While he expects to see some institutional demand, retail interest is less certain, the trader said. Included in that total is a $713 million New Jersey Transporatation Trust Fund Authority offering through competitive sale.
"Retail is just not a participant right now," he said.

Tuesday's actively quoted secondary issues included Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority's 5-1/4 percent bonds of March 2020. The bonds were bid at a 5.76 percent net yield, versus a 5.73 percent net yield for Monday closing bid.
In debt futures, the December municipal contract was down 3/32 at 114-3/32. The December T-bond contract was down 3/32 at 110-31/32. The MOB spread was 100.
In the government market, the benchmark 30-year bond was down 6/32 at 99-3/32 to yield 6.82 percent.
